entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French blamer, blasmer, from Late Latin blasphemare to blaspheme, from Greek blasphēmein

def.dt: :to find fault with :censure the right to praise or blame a literary work
:to hold responsible they blame me for everything
:to place responsibility for blames it on me
:at fault :responsible says he's not to blame for the accident

entry.pt: Use of blame in sense 2b with on has occasionally been disparaged as wrong. Such disparagement is without basis; blame on occurs as frequently in carefully edited prose as blame for. Both are standard.

def.dt: :responsibility for something believed to deserve censure they must share the blame
